sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the matrix:

A = 
\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 4 & 5 \\
-1 & 3 & 6 \\
0 & 7 & -2
\end{bmatrix}
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix A:

\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i
\end{bmatrix}

In our case, the matrix A is:

\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 4 & 5 \\
-1 & 3 & 6 \\
0 & 7 & -2
\end{bmatrix}

So, a = 2, b = 4, c = 5, d = -1, e = 3, f = 6, g = 0, h = 7, and i = -2.

Now, we can plug these values into the determinant formula:

det(A) = 2(3(-2) - 6(7)) - 4((-1)(-2) - 6(0)) + 5((-1)(7) - 3(0))
det(A) = 2(-6 - 42) - 4(2) + 5(-7)
det(A) = 2(-48) - 8 - 35
det(A) = -96 - 8 - 35
det(A) = -139

So, the determinant of the matrix A is -139.
